body: @IamJaz, you need the DEEPLABCUT_M1.yaml file rather. Have a look at the instructions [here](https://deeplabcut.github.io/DeepLabCut/docs/recipes/installTips.html?highlight=m1#deeplabcut-m1-chip-installation-environment-instructions), this will get you the right tensorflow and python version.

> @IamJaz, you need the DEEPLABCUT_M1.yaml file rather. Have a look at the instructions [here](https://deeplabcut.github.io/DeepLabCut/docs/recipes/installTips.html?highlight=m1#deeplabcut-m1-chip-installation-environment-instructions), this will get you the right tensorflow and python version.

Hi @jeylau , thank you for getting back to me. I tried with the M1 yaml file initially and it also did not work. I do not remember the error message. I removed every DLC file from my computer and restarted the whole installation by following the guidelines you linked. I am using python 3.9 and after I run : conda env create -f DEEPLABCUT_M1.yaml , I get this error message:

Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed

ResolvePackageNotFound: 
  - python=3.7

I also tried installing python 3.7 using brew and resolving some packages but I still cannot get it to work. Any piece of advice is most welcome!
check out the instructions within the M1 yaml file; you need to use python 3.7 not 3.9 actually, as you need to first install a specific version of TF for apple.
that being said, the M1/M2 is an issue in terms of smoothness of install, and we are actively working on making this better; see at PR #1970

> Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done Solving environment: failed
> 
> ResolvePackageNotFound:
> 
> * python=3.7

Hi @IamJaz. I'm not at all a DLC expert but I tried to install DLC on an M1 recently and had the same trouble. I think the error above comes from the fact that there is no python3.7 on conda for the new arm64 Mac architecture. Also [the instructions](https://deeplabcut.github.io/DeepLabCut/docs/recipes/installTips.html?highlight=m1#deeplabcut-m1-chip-installation-environment-instructions) tell you that you should use "Rosetta wheel for TensorFlow", which means you should run things as if you were using an old Mac with x86 chip using Rosetta for translation. To do that you need to convert your conda environment (I'm not sure why this isn't explained anywhere in the installation instructions, but it's a very common procedure also for other Python packages). What has worked for me is:
1. Create a new empty environment:
```
conda create -n DEEPLABCUT_M1
```
2. Activate the environment and set it to use the old x86 architecture:
```
conda activate DEEPLABCUT_M1
conda env config vars set CONDA_SUBDIR=osx-64
``` 
3. To make the change effective, deactivate and reactivate the environment:
```
conda deactivate
conda activate DEEPLABCUT_M1
```
4. Use the ```DEEPLABCUT_M1.yaml``` file to install necessary software:
```
conda env update -f DEEPLABCUT_M1.yml
```
5. Force re-install tensorflow as explained in the instructions:
```
pip install tensorflow-2.4.1-py3-none-any.whl --no-dependencies --force-reinstall
```

Now you should be able to start deeplabcut with ```pythonw -m deeplabcut ```. Note that this won't use your GPU and also not exploit the CPU optimally as it will "translate" the code.

Hey @guiwitz super, thanks! would you like to make a PR with the changes to the docs for this? https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/master/docs/recipes/installTips.md#deeplabcut-m1-chip-installation-environment-instructions

body:
Hi everyone, 

Apologies for the late reply! 

@guiwitz thank you for sharing what you did. I tried it on my end and still can't get it to work. Despite using the right yaml file and specifying the folder where it is, after I did this step "conda env update -f DEEPLABCUT_M1.ym", I  got a  very long error report. At the end, it said: 

"An unexpected error has occurred. Conda has prepared the above report.

If submitted, this report will be used by core maintainers to improve
future releases of conda.
Would you like conda to send this report to the core maintainers? [y/N]:"

But somewhere above, I also noticed this: "conda-build version : not installed". Could it explain why I am not able to make it work and do you know how I can change this? 

Thanks lot for your help,

Jaz
@IamJaz this seems a bit odd. Can you print the output of ```conda info``` ?

@guiwitz conda info gives this: 

     active environment : base
    active env location : /Users/miniconda3
            shell level : 1
       user config file : /Users/.condarc
 populated config files : /Users/.condarc
          conda version : 22.9.0
    conda-build version : not installed
         python version : 3.9.12.final.0
       virtual packages : __osx=12.6=0
                          __unix=0=0
                          __archspec=1=arm64
       base environment : /Users/miniconda3  (writable)
      conda av data dir : /Users/miniconda3/etc/conda
  conda av metadata url : None
           channel URLs : https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/osx-arm64
                          https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch
                          https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/free/osx-arm64
                          https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/free/noarch
                          https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/osx-arm64
                          https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/noarch
          package cache : /Users/miniconda3/pkgs
                          /Users/.conda/pkgs
       envs directories : /Users/miniconda3/envs
                          /Users/.conda/envs
               platform : osx-arm64
             user-agent : conda/22.9.0 requests/2.27.1 CPython/3.9.12 Darwin/21.6.0 OSX/12.6
                UID:GID : 501:20
             netrc file : None
           offline mode : False
@IamJaz This looks ok but you are using the most recent version of conda, so maybe something broke there. Can you post the complete error trace?
